The many lives and deaths of Ursula Todd are related, interlocked and grow in and out of each other in Kate Atkinson's new novel ""Life after Life."" And Kate Atkinson, the Whitbread Award-winning author of previous novels, including ""Case Histories,"" joins us from the BBC in Edinburgh.
Thanks so much for being with us.
Yeah, it's a pleasure.
This novel is so intricately plotted.
I have to ask did you write it out on shirt cardboards, index cards, a tapestry, like the, you know, Bayeux Tapestry?
Is this all done by computer program?
How'd you manage it?
This, to me, was much easier to write than the previous four novels because they were, to all intents and purposes, crime novels - and they are tapestries.
That's a very good analogy for them because it's two steps forward, one step back.
You're always going back and putting something in because it's all about clues and plotting.
Why is this?
Because I knew where I was going to start and I knew where I wanted to end, and I knew that it was all about being born.
It was always going to come back to February the 11th, 1910 in a snowstorm.
So, it's a much more rhythmic way of writing.
I just started at the beginning and wrote to the end.
It was actually relatively easy.
As I've been telling people, this is not, to my mind, a novel about the road not taken, so much as this is a book that takes every road.
(LAUGHTER)
Yes.
That's true.
Which prompts the question, is Ursula Todd the same character life after life?
Yes.
She's definitely the same character.
But I think what happens is, I mean, she has all these lives but she learns and she doesn't always correct.
And she certainly doesn't always correct in the right way.
But she changes and she changes things.
Not that she improves herself.
I think that she gets stronger and she gets more courageous.

So, it changes, it alters.

Sometimes it's poignant.

The Blitz is - for those of us who love Britain - this is the odyssey.

Well, I was born in '51, so in a way I just missed it.

And I think with the Blitz, I think it's such an intense period.
I forget how many days - it's 57 or 58 days of continuous bombing or nighttime continuous bombing, sometimes daytime bombing.
And you do wonder what affect that has on character and on how people feel.
So, I read a lot of firsthand accounts and was impressed really by the stoicism.
I think out of all the words I would use for how people behaved, it would be stoic.
You know, you have to peel away lots of layers of propaganda because there was an immense amount of propaganda in Britain in the Second World War, which was deemed necessary to keep morale up.
